727570f-b.title: Queens: Northern Boulevard - Main Street
727570f-b.text:
orthern Boulevard, south side, east of Main St., showing in a
set of three views the Quaker Meeting House of Flushing. The land
upon which this building was erected;from 1694-57was puchased in
1692 for the sum of f 40. On May 30, 1696 their first annual meeting
was held here. This building was shingled plastered, and repaired in
1704. The Quaker records state1 A new building was erected in 1719
near the old one and was 65'x42' in size. This refers probably to an
addition. In 1763, the gallery was taken out and a floor was laid,
making it a two story structure. The British used the structure as
a barrack, hospital, prison, and bay magazine; being restored to
the original owner in 1783. The Orthodox Quakers built a meeting
house east of the old (Hicksite), meeting house in the 183O's. The
picket fence surrounding this building as removed in 1911, and the
Orthodox Meeting House in 1909
1922
View 2: March 1924.
View 3: July 1925.
727570f-b.folder: Northern Boulevard & Main Street, Queens, NY

727575f-a.title: Queens: Northern Boulevard - Main Street
727575f-a.text:
Northern Boulevard, south side, eest from 'ain 3treet. n
the left is a small puolic park which separates the boulevard
in twain. he second house from the right is the 1. Prost
house of 1873, and beyond it is the old Cuaker Heeting House.
View 2 shows the same area some years later. vast changes
have taken place here. The former eountry-like atmosphere
has change into one of a thriving business district.
View 1 Eugene L. Armoruster Collection  19EE
MAY BE REPRODUCED
View 2: P.L. Sperr  ay 27, 1939

727330f-a.title: Queens: Main Street - Northern Boulevard
727330f-a.text:
Main Street (foreground), at the S.E. corner of Northern Boulevard,
showing the Fountain House. In 183O Benj. P. Lowerre, later Charles
P. Lowerre, and in 1873 the C.P. Lowerre Estate owned this tavern.
Eucene L. Armbruster states that Jacob F. Haubeil was long the owner of
this tavern. He lived at 136 Broadway and never lived in the Fountain
House. Bis pater operated, built, and owned the Washington Hotel in
1855. The building in this view does not appear in the Queens Atlas of
1926.
1922.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
MAY BE REPRODUCED.

727568f-b.title: Queens: Northern Boulevard - Main Street
727568f-b.text:
Northern Boulevard, south side, east of Main Street,
showing three views (from three different angles) of the
Suaker Meeting House of Flushing, built in 1694. The
)uakers held their first annual meeting here on May 30th,
1696. The British, during the Revolution, used the struc.
ture as a barrack, hospital, prison and bay magazine.
View 1: 1922
Views 2,3: July, 1925
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection
MAY BE REPRODU:ED

727326f-a.title: Queens: Main Street - Northern Boulevard
727326f-a.text:
Main Street, west side, south of Northern Boulevard to Thirty-
ninth Ave. St. George's Protestant Episcopal Church is in the back-
ground on Thirty-ninth Ave. TThe brick front structure next to the one
bearing the sign plate W. Follet was the parsonage of this church and
was occupied by the Rev. Barzillai from 1809-1820. It is now designated
Nos. 37-39 Main Street.
1922.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
MAY BE REPRODUCED.
727326f-a.folder: Main Street & Northern Boulevard, Queens, NY

727327f-a.title: Queens: Main Street - Northern Boulevard
727327f-a.text:
Main St., (old Nos. 11,13,l5) west side, south of Northern
Boulevard. Caleb W. Smith, left foreground, lived here in 1870.
He operated a candy store. Geo Barron occupied the center house.
He was a friend of Smith's. Mr. Barron kept a clothing store here.
He died in this small house in 1926. Woolworth store occupies
the site in 1922.
1922
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection
MAY BE REPRODUCED.

center of Northern Boulevard, forming a safety aisle for east and
west traffic.
1923.
Eucene L. Armbruster Collection.

727569f-a.title: Queens: Northern Boulevard - Main Street
727569f-a.text:
Northern Boulevard, south side, east of Main St., showing in
a set of 4 views the rear and side of the Quaker Meeting house,
erected in 1694. The lock on the inside is encased in an oak
block about 8'x14''l 1V2'' and is fastened by hand made screws.
It is the original lock. The wood burning stoves, found still
in service here, were imported from England over two hundred years
Sgo. The heat is distributed by pipes extending along the ceiling.
July 1925.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection
MAY BE REPRODUCED.
727569f-a.folder: Northern Boulevard & Main Street, Queens, NY
